results.title: Low myocardial energetic efficiency is associated with increased mortality in aortic stenosis
results.text_hl: Data from 1703 @SPECIES_9606 @@@patients@@@ with mostly moderate @<m>DISEASE_Aortic_Valve_Stenosis</m> @DISEASE_MESH:D001024 @@@AS@@@ enrolled in the @<m>CHEMICAL_Ezetimibe_Simvastatin_Drug_Combination</m> @CHEMICAL_MESH:D000069499 @@@Simvastatin and Ezetimibe@@@ in @<m>DISEASE_Aortic_Valve_Stenosis</m> @DISEASE_MESH:D001024 @@@Aortic Stenosis@@@ study followed for 4.3 years was used.

citations.NLM: Bahlmann E, Einarsen E, Cramariuc D, Midtbø H, Mancusi C, Rossebø A, Willems S, Gerdts E. Low myocardial energetic efficiency is associated with increased mortality in aortic stenosis Open Heart. 2021 Aug;8(2):. PMID: 34426527
citations.BibTeX: @article{34426527, title={Low myocardial energetic efficiency is associated with increased mortality in aortic stenosis}, author={Bahlmann E and Einarsen E and Cramariuc D and Midtbø H and Mancusi C and Rossebø A and Willems S and Gerdts E}, journal={Open Heart}, volume={8}, number={2}}

results.title: Sudden cardiac death in asymptomatic patients with aortic stenosis.
results.text_hl: OBJECTIVE: We retrospectively analysed outcome data from the @<m>CHEMICAL_Ezetimibe_Simvastatin_Drug_Combination</m> @CHEMICAL_MESH:D000069499 @@@Simvastatin and Ezetimibe@@@ in @<m>DISEASE_Aortic_Valve_Stenosis</m> @DISEASE_MESH:D001024 @@@Aortic Stenosis@@@ (SEAS) study to assess the incidence and potential risk factors of @DISEASE_Death_Sudden_Cardiac @DISEASE_MESH:D016757 @@@sudden cardiac death@@@ (@DISEASE_Death_Sudden_Cardiac @DISEASE_MESH:D016757 @@@SCD@@@) in this prospectively followed cohort of asymptomatic @SPECIES_9606 @@@patients@@@ with @<m>DISEASE_Aortic_Valve_Stenosis</m> @DISEASE_MESH:D001024 @@@aortic stenosis@@@ (AS).

citations.NLM: Minners J, Rossebo A, Chambers JB, Gohlke-Baerwolf C, Neumann FJ, Wachtell K, Jander N. Sudden cardiac death in asymptomatic patients with aortic stenosis. Heart. 2020 Nov;106(21):1646-1650. PMID: 32737125
citations.BibTeX: @article{32737125, title={Sudden cardiac death in asymptomatic patients with aortic stenosis.}, author={Minners J and Rossebo A and Chambers JB and Gohlke-Baerwolf C and Neumann FJ and Wachtell K and Jander N}, journal={Heart}, volume={106}, number={21}, pages={1646-1650}}

results.title: Prognostic impact of impaired left ventricular midwall function during progression of aortic stenosis.
results.text_hl: METHODS: One thousand four hundred seventy-eight @SPECIES_9606 @@@patients@@@ with asymptomatic AS and normal EF (>=50%) at baseline in the @<m>CHEMICAL_Ezetimibe_Simvastatin_Drug_Combination</m> @CHEMICAL_MESH:D000069499 @@@Simvastatin Ezetimibe@@@ in @<m>DISEASE_Aortic_Valve_Stenosis</m> @DISEASE_MESH:D001024 @@@Aortic Stenosis@@@ (SEAS) study were followed for a median of 4.3 years.

citations.NLM: Cramariuc D, Bahlmann E, Egstrup K, Rossebø AB, Ray S, Kesäniemi YA, Nienaber CA, Gerdts E. Prognostic impact of impaired left ventricular midwall function during progression of aortic stenosis. Echocardiography. 2021 Jan;38(1):31-38. PMID: 33146452
citations.BibTeX: @article{33146452, title={Prognostic impact of impaired left ventricular midwall function during progression of aortic stenosis.}, author={Cramariuc D and Bahlmann E and Egstrup K and Rossebø AB and Ray S and Kesäniemi YA and Nienaber CA and Gerdts E}, journal={Echocardiography}, volume={38}, number={1}, pages={31-38}}

results.title: Higher Acceleration/Ejection Time Ratio Predicts Impaired Outcome in Aortic Valve Stenosis.
results.text_hl: @SPECIES_9606 @@@Patients@@@ were part of the SEAS study (@<m>CHEMICAL_Ezetimibe_Simvastatin_Drug_Combination</m> @CHEMICAL_MESH:D000069499 @@@Simvastatin Ezetimibe@@@ @<m>DISEASE_Aortic_Valve_Stenosis</m> @DISEASE_MESH:D001024 @@@Aortic Stenosis@@@).

citations.NLM: Einarsen E, Cramariuc D, Bahlmann E, Midtbo H, Chambers JB, Gerdts E. Higher Acceleration/Ejection Time Ratio Predicts Impaired Outcome in Aortic Valve Stenosis. Circ Cardiovasc Imaging. 2021 Jan;14(1):e011467. PMID: 33461302
citations.BibTeX: @article{33461302, title={Higher Acceleration/Ejection Time Ratio Predicts Impaired Outcome in Aortic Valve Stenosis.}, author={Einarsen E and Cramariuc D and Bahlmann E and Midtbo H and Chambers JB and Gerdts E}, journal={Circ Cardiovasc Imaging}, volume={14}, number={1}, pages={e011467}}

results.title: Impact of sex-specific thresholds for low flow in assessment of prognosis in concordantly and discordantly graded aortic valve stenosis.
results.text_hl: METHODS: Data from 1351 @SPECIES_9606 @@@patients@@@ with asymptomatic @<m>DISEASE_Aortic_Valve_Stenosis</m> @DISEASE_MESH:D001024 @@@AS@@@, peak jet velocity <4m/s and preserved left ventricular ejection fraction enrolled in the @<m>CHEMICAL_Ezetimibe_Simvastatin_Drug_Combination</m> @CHEMICAL_MESH:D000069499 @@@Simvastatin and Ezetimibe@@@ in @<m>DISEASE_Aortic_Valve_Stenosis</m> @DISEASE_MESH:D001024 @@@AS@@@ study was used.

citations.NLM: Bahlmann E, Gerdts E, Einarsen E, Midtbø H, Pedersen ER, Rossebø A, Willems S, Cramariuc D. Impact of sex-specific thresholds for low flow in assessment of prognosis in concordantly and discordantly graded aortic valve stenosis. Eur Heart J Cardiovasc Imaging. 2024 Oct 28;():. PMID: 39467305

results.title: Prospective Evaluation of Malignancy in 17,708 Patients Randomized to Ezetimibe Versus Placebo
results.text_hl: An increased risk of @DISEASE_Neoplasms @DISEASE_MESH:D009369 @@@malignancy@@@ was reported with @<m>CHEMICAL_Ezetimibe_Simvastatin_Drug_Combination</m> @CHEMICAL_MESH:D000069499 @@@simvastatin/ezetimibe@@@ in 1,873 @SPECIES_9606 @@@patients@@@ in the SEAS (@<m>CHEMICAL_Ezetimibe_Simvastatin_Drug_Combination</m> @CHEMICAL_MESH:D000069499 @@@Simvastatin and Ezetimibe@@@ in @<m>DISEASE_Aortic_Valve_Stenosis</m> @DISEASE_MESH:D001024 @@@Aortic Stenosis@@@) trial.

citations.NLM: Giugliano RP, Gencer B, Wiviott SD, Park JG, Fuchs CS, Goessling W, Musliner TA, Tershakovec AM, Blazing MA, Califf R, Cannon CP, Braunwald E. Prospective Evaluation of Malignancy in 17,708 Patients Randomized to Ezetimibe Versus Placebo JACC CardioOncol. 2020 Sep;2(3):385-396. PMID: 34396246
